newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Container ship sinks off S.Korea, crews rescued.
newsitem.headline: Container ship sinks off S.Korea, crews rescued.

text.p: A South Korean container ship sank after colliding with another ship early Wednesday off a southern South Korean coast, but all the 11 crew members on board the sunken vessel were rescued, maritime police said.
An officer at the Pusan Maritime Police said by telephone a small amount of fuel oil leaked from the 1,921 gross tonne Jang Yung Lotus after it sank, but said the spill was not serious.
"There was some oil leakage, but the amount is negligible because it's only a small part of the 48 tonnes of Bunker C oil carried by the Jang Yung Lotus," he said.
He said the ship was bound for Moji, Japan, after departing the port of Pusan at around 1:20 a.m. (1620 GMT Tuesday) when it collided in dense fog with the 2,854-gross-ton Lucky Star.
Lucky Star is owned by Nam Sung Shipping Co and Jang Yung Lotus by Jang Yung Line Co, both based in Seoul.
All the 11 crewmembers aboard the Jang Yung Lotus were rescued immediately by the Lucky Star, which returned to the Pusan port several hours later, he said.
He said the sunken vessel was carrying 45 containers filled with unspecified cargo, and several of them were still afloat.
"We are more concerned about these containers floating than about the oil spilt because other ships could hit them as it gets darker," he said.
